page.title: 09Land usage of Beeley Moor
page.content: Due to variations in land height and soil fertility the type of farming may be classified as mixed farming. The Hipper valley farmland consists of grassland for silage and hay, enclosed rough grazing and moorland. Due to the steepness of the terain few crops are grown. The farmland in the south east of the area is worked in a similar way but in addition crops such as barley, corn and potatoes are grown. Two farms have Friesian dairy herds and the milk is collected by tanker. Other farms have cattle for beef and some have small flocks of sheep, the commonest breeds being Swaledale and Suffolk mules. {FARM MACHINERY:-}small machinery such as tractors with harrows and ploughs are used. Where large machinery is needed, such as combine harvesters, contractors are used.
